title: 103_hr2535
content: AUTHORITY TO PROVIDE PRIORITY HEALTH CARE TO VETERANS OF THE PERSIAN GULF WAR. Inpatient care eligibility for veterans exposed to environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War is expanded under title 38, United States Code. Veterans with potential exposure to toxic substances are now eligible for hospital and nursing home care, even without conclusive medical evidence linking their disability to the exposure. In outpatient care, eligibility for veterans exposed to toxic substances during the Persian Gulf War is expanded under title 38, United States Code. Veterans with potential exposure to environmental hazards are now eligible for care, even without conclusive medical evidence linking their disability to the exposure. The amendments to title 38, United States Code expand eligibility for medical services for veterans exposed to toxic substances during the Persian Gulf War. Veterans may receive care even without conclusive medical evidence linking their disability to the exposure. The effective date of these amendments is August 2, 1990, and veterans who paid for services before the enactment of this Act may request reimbursement. The Act extends eligibility for medical services to veterans exposed to toxic substances during the Persian Gulf War. Veterans who paid for services before the Act may request reimbursement. Additionally, the Act extends eligibility for care related to exposure to dioxin or ionizing radiation and sexual trauma counseling. The Act extends eligibility for medical services to veterans exposed to toxic substances during the Persian Gulf War, including care related to exposure to dioxin or ionizing radiation and sexual trauma counseling. Amendments are made to various sections, changing dates to extend eligibility for services until December 31, 1994. The Act extends eligibility for medical services to veterans exposed to toxic substances during the Persian Gulf War, including care related to exposure to dioxin or ionizing radiation and sexual trauma counseling. Amendments are made to various sections, changing dates to extend eligibility for services until December 31, 1994. SEC. 3. SHARING OF RESOURCES WITH STATE HOMES. The Act aims to improve care for veterans by allowing the Secretary to make agreements with State veterans facilities to share health-care resources, including hospital care, medical services, and rehabilitative services. The definition of 'health-care resource' is expanded to include various services and administrative resources. Sharing of health-care resources is facilitated through mutual agreements for use or exchange. The Act allows the Secretary to make agreements with State veterans facilities to share health-care resources, including specialized medical resources and health-care resources. The Secretary may enter into agreements only if they obviate the need for similar resources in Department health care facilities or if Department resources justified for veterans' care are not used to their maximum capacity. The curr_chunk is about the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States, who also serves as the President of the Senate.
